com.studiomediatech.queryresponse

Class ChainingQueryBuilder<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.studiomediatech.queryresponse.ChainingQueryBuilder<T>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - the coerced type of the query's response element collection.

    public final class ChainingQueryBuilder<T>
extends Object
    Provides the entry to the fluid builder for queries, with the queryFor(java.lang.String, java.lang.Class<T>) method.

    You begin building a query by calling the static method like this:

           QueryBuilder.queryFor("some-query", SomeType.class)...

    A queryBuilder-instance is a container for a composed or configured query. It is is much like a command-pattern object, providing all the properties required in order to publish the query, await responses and return the results.

    • Method Detail

      • waitingFor

        public ChainingQueryBuilder<T> waitingFor(long millis)
        Set the approximate duration, in milliseconds, that the query will block for when being executed.

        The actual blocking time is not exact. The current contract will ensure blocking for at least the amount of time specified.

        Queries are always bound to a blocking timeout, and will return after at most the given duration. Combined with the taking... conditionals (takingAtLeast(int) or takingAtMost(int)), this can be used to either return earlier, use a default or fail.

        Parameters:
        millis - duration to block on the calling thread. At the most Long.MAX_VALUE milliseconds is allowed.
        Returns:
        the query builder, for chaining further calls
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - for any 0, negative or too long duration.

      • waitingFor

        public ChainingQueryBuilder<T> waitingFor(long amount,
                                          TemporalUnit timeUnit)
        Set the duration and temporal unit, to block for when issuing a query.
        Parameters:
        amount - the amount of the duration to block on the calling thread. An amount representing the duration of at the most Long.MAX_VALUE milliseconds is allowed.
        timeUnit - the unit of the blocking duration
        Returns:
        the query builder, for chaining further calls
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - for any 0, negative or too long duration.
        See Also:
        waitingFor(long)

      • waitingFor

        public ChainingQueryBuilder<T> waitingFor(Duration duration)
        Set the duration to block for when issuing a query.
        Parameters:
        duration - to block on the calling thread. A duration of at the most Long.MAX_VALUE milliseconds is allowed.
        Returns:
        the query builder, for chaining further calls
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - for any 0, negative or too long duration.
        See Also:
        waitingFor(long)

      • takingAtMost

        public ChainingQueryBuilder<T> takingAtMost(int atMost)
        Sets the maximum number of elements to consume from responses, effectively limiting the returned results.

        Queries always block for a specified duration.Combined with this specified amount of maximum elements to consume, the query can be made to return earlier.

        Parameters:
        atMost - number of elements to consume, must be greater than 0.
        Returns:
        the query builder, for chaining further calls
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - for any values less than 1

      • takingAtLeast

        public ChainingQueryBuilder<T> takingAtLeast(int atLeast)
        Sets the required amount of result elements for the query.
        Parameters:
        atLeast - number of elements required, for the query to be successful, must be an amount greater than 0, and cannot be lower than a previous call to takingAtMost has set as a limit
        Returns:
        the query builder, for chaining further calls

        public ChainingQueryBuilder<T> onError(Consumer<Throwable> handler)

        Parameters:

        Returns:
        the query builder, for chaining further calls

      • orEmpty

        public Collection<T> orEmpty()

        Returns:

      • orDefaults

        public Collection<T> orDefaults(Collection<T> defaults)
        Sets the default results collection to use, for a failing query.
        Parameters:

        Returns:
        the query builder, for chaining further calls

      • orDefaults

        public Collection<T> orDefaults(Supplier<Collection<T>> defaults)
        Sets the default results supplier to use, for a failing query. The supplier is only invoked if the query fails.
        Parameters:
        defaults - collection provider, for results to use if the query fails
        Returns:
        the query builder, for chaining further calls

      • orThrow

        public Collection<T> orThrow(Supplier<RuntimeException> throwable)
        Sets a throwable supplier, to be invoked in case the query fails.
        Parameters:
        throwable - supplier, invoked to get a throwable to throw in case the query fails
        Returns:
        the query builder, for chaining further calls

      • withSink

        protected ChainingQueryBuilder<T> withSink(Consumer<ChainingQueryBuilder<T>> sink)
        Replaces the current sink for this builder, effectively removing the registry and instead making the terminal operation apply this builder on the provided consumer. Calling this method will short-circuit, and always return null. However the builder can be captured for tests, as in the example below: 
               AtomicReference<QueryBuilder<String>> capture = new AtomicReference<>(null);

       QueryBuilder.queryFor("foobar", String.class).withSink(capture::set).waitingFor(123).orEmpty();

       assertThat(capture.get()).isNotNull();

        This method is protected, in order to reduce visibility and only make it available to tests.

        Parameters:
        sink - to consume this builder, in the terminal operation call to any orXYZ(..) methods, and return the results null.
        Returns:
        this builder, for chaining.
